Terminology of experiments
Objective
A desired change in outcome
https://www.coursera.org/learn/experimentation/lecture/oaSsT/1b-some-basic-terminology
Terminology of experiments
The way numeric and categorical factors differ in terms of their possible values
Categorical factors can only take the limited set of values, while numeric ones may, at least in principle, take values in-between those tested as well.
"Experimentation for Improvement" MOOC, taught by Kevin Dunn from McMaster University
Terminology of experiments
What distinguishes an ordinal variable/factor from an interval variable/factor?
For ordinal variables the difference between two values is not meaningful (eg. movie ratings), while for interval variables the difference is meaningful (eg. between 90 and 100 degrees).
"Experimentation for Improvement" MOOC, taught by Kevin Dunn from McMaster University
What is the main difference between interval and ratio variables/factors?
Interval variables don't have a meaningful 0, while ratio ones do.
"Experimentation for Improvement" MOOC, taught by Kevin Dunn from McMaster University
Terminology of experiments
Why are ratio variables named as they are?
Because for such variables it is meaningful to compare ratios of different values.
http://www.graphpad.com/support/faqid/1089/
Terminology of experiments
What are the 4 basic ways of visualising 2-factor experiments using pen and paper?
Table, cube plot, contour plot, interaction plot
"Experimentation for Improvement" MOOC, taught by Kevin Dunn from McMaster University
The prediction formula for a 2-factor experiment
baseline + b<sub>A</sub> * x<sub>A</sub> + b<sub>B</sub> * x<sub>B</sub> + interaction *x<sub>A </sub>*x<sub>B</sub>
"Experimentation for Improvement" MOOC, taught by Kevin Dunn from McMaster University
(A factor's) main effect
The average of the outcome changes created by that factor.

because it's meaningful to say that

Terminology of experiments
Disturbance
A variable that's not controlled, nor measured, but affects the output.
"Experimentation for Improvement" MOOC, taught by Kevin Dunn from McMaster University
Terminology of experiments
Covariate
A variable (that might impact our outcome) that's not controlled, but measured
"Experimentation for Improvement" MOOC, taught by Kevin Dunn from McMaster University
Terminology of experiments
Difference between covariates and disturbances
We can measure covariates, unlike disturbances
"Experimentation for Improvement" MOOC, taught by Kevin Dunn from McMaster University
Terminology of experiments
Nuisance variable
Variable that is measurable and controllable, but is not the focus of the experiment
"Experimentation for Improvement" MOOC, taught by Kevin Dunn from McMaster University
Terminology of experiments
Question for determining whether a variable is a nuisance variable and therefore should be blocked
"Does the process have to work successfully with different levels of this variable in the future?"

It's recommended to start with a baseline experiment. What values are the variables set to?
0 (or their centers), or the most convenient setting for categorical factors

two factor interactions

Measure and add them next to the factors.

Formula for calculating the coded value corresponding to a real-world value
\[\frac{realValue - centerValue}{\frac{1}{2}(value_{+1} - value_{-1})}\]

Formula for calculating the real-world value corresponding to the center (0) coded value
\[\frac{value_{-1} + value_{+1}}{2}\]

Formula for calculating the real-world value corresponding to a coded value
\[codedValue * \frac{1}{2}range + centerValue\]

25% of the extreme range

\[2^{\frac{k}{4}}\], where k = number of factorial runs

the factorial points

In a central composite design, which experiment runs are recommended to be run last?
the star points

What do central composite designs add to factorial designs in terms of experimental runs?
a group of star points where to run experiments

Optimization experiments
Why central composite designs add a group of star points to factorial designs
to allow a better estimation of curvature (interaction)

If the outcome at a new point in the steepest direction is accurately predicted by the latest model, it's recommended to
keep going in that direction until the prediction becomes inadequate

lm(y ~ A + B)

lm(y ~ A * B)

How do we know when to stop running optimization experiments?
When the model's predicted surface accurately matches reality

Evolutionary Operation (EVOP)
Continually running factorial experiments to keep tracking the moving optimum

The two steps to find the predicted maximum of a quadratic two-factor model

1. differentiating the y = ... equation with respect to the coded variables
2. solving the resulting two-equation system

The first step (of two) for finding the predicted maximum of a quadratic two-factor model
differentiating the factorial equation with respect to the coded variables
